input.content:
You are an AI assistant tasked with solving command-line tasks in a Linux environment. You will be given a task description and the output from previously executed commands. Your goal is to solve the task by providing batches of shell commands.

Format your response as JSON with the following structure:

{
  "analysis": "Analyze the current state based on the terminal output provided. What do you see? What has been accomplished? What still needs to be done?",
  "plan": "Describe your plan for the next steps. What commands will you run and why? Be specific about what you expect each command to accomplish.",
  "commands": [
    {
      "keystrokes": "ls -la\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    },
    {
      "keystrokes": "cd project\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    }
  ],
  "task_complete": true
}

Required fields:
- "analysis": Your analysis of the current situation
- "plan": Your plan for the next steps
- "commands": Array of command objects to execute

Optional fields:
- "task_complete": Boolean indicating if the task is complete (defaults to false if not present)

Command object structure:
- "keystrokes": String containing the exact keystrokes to send to the terminal (required)
- "duration": Number of seconds to wait for the command to complete before the next command will be executed (defaults to 1.0 if not present)

IMPORTANT: The text inside "keystrokes" will be used completely verbatim as keystrokes. Write commands exactly as you want them sent to the terminal:
- You must end every command with a newline (\n) or it will not execute.
- For special key sequences, use tmux-style escape sequences:
  - C-c for Ctrl+C
  - C-d for Ctrl+D

The "duration" attribute specifies the number of seconds to wait for the command to complete (default: 1.0) before the next command will be executed. On immediate tasks (e.g., cd, ls, echo, cat) set a duration of 0.1 seconds. On commands (e.g., gcc, find, rustc) set a duration of 1.0 seconds. On slow commands (e.g., make, python3 [long running script], wget [file]) set an appropriate duration as you determine necessary.

It is better to set a smaller duration than a longer duration. It is always possible to wait again if the prior output has not finished, by running {"keystrokes": "", "duration": 10.0} on subsequent requests to wait longer. Never wait longer than 60 seconds; prefer to poll to see intermediate result status.

Important notes:
- Each command's keystrokes are sent exactly as written to the terminal
- Do not include extra whitespace before or after the keystrokes unless it's part of the intended command
- Extra text before or after the JSON will generate warnings but be tolerated
- The JSON must be valid - use proper escaping for quotes and special characters within strings
- Commands array can be empty if you want to wait without taking action

Task Description:
I will ask you a question, then you should help me operate a MySQL database with SQL to answer the question.
You have to explain the problem and your solution to me and write down your thoughts.
After thinking and explaining thoroughly, every round you can choose to operate or to answer.
your operation should be like this:
Action: Operation
```sql
SELECT * FROM table WHERE condition;
```
You MUST put SQL in markdown format without any other comments. Your SQL should be in one line.
Every time you can only execute one SQL statement. I will only execute the statement in the first SQL code block. Every time you write a SQL, I will execute it for you and give you the output.
If you are done operating, and you want to commit your final answer, then write down:
Action: Answer
Final Answer: ["ANSWER1", "ANSWER2", ...]
DO NOT write this pattern unless you are sure about your answer. I expect an accurate and correct answer.
Your answer should be accurate. Your answer must be exactly the same as the correct answer.
If the question is about modifying the database, then after done operation, your answer field can be anything.
If your response cannot match any pattern I mentioned earlier, you will be judged as FAIL immediately.
Your input will be raw MySQL response, you have to deal with it by yourself.

Current terminal state:
Current Terminal Screen:
bash: cannot set terminal process group (-1): Inappropriate ioctl for device
bash: no job control in this shell
root@2178bed1d79c:/app#

New Terminal Output:

root@2178bed1d79c:/app# pwd
/app
root@2178bed1d79c:/app# ls -la /app
total 8
drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 4096 Sep 17 18:16 .
drwxr-xr-x 1 root root 4096 Jan  7 21:44 ..
root@2178bed1d79c:/app# env | grep -i mysql || true
root@2178bed1d79c:/app# which mysql || true
root@2178bed1d79c:/app# mysql --version || true
bash: mysql: command not found
root@2178bed1d79c:/app# ps aux | grep -E 'mysqld|mysql' | grep -v grep || true
root@2178bed1d79c:/app# ss -ltnp | grep 3306 || true
bash: ss: command not found
root@2178bed1d79c:/app# ls -la /var/lib/mysql || true
ls: cannot access '/var/lib/mysql': No such file or directory
root@2178bed1d79c:/app# test -f /etc/mysql/my.cnf && sed -n '1,200p' /etc/mysql/my.cnf || true
root@2178bed1d79c:/app#

New Terminal Output:

root@2178bed1d79c:/app#

New Terminal Output:

root@2178bed1d79c:/app#

{
  "analysis": "No new activity in the terminal. From earlier checks: this container has no MySQL client or server installed, /app is empty, there are no MySQL environment variables, no mysqld process, and no MySQL data/config present. Therefore I cannot run any SQL here until you either (A) provide a remote MySQL server (host, port, user, password) so I can craft SQL for you to run, or (B) allow me to install a MySQL/MariaDB client (and optionally server) in this container so I can execute queries locally.",
  "plan": "I will wait for you to do one of the following and then proceed:

1) Provide the database question you want answered and (optionally) remote DB connection details. If you only provide the question, I will explain my approach and then supply exactly one SQL statement (in the required single SQL code block) for you to execute against your database. After you run it and return the raw MySQL output, I'll parse it and continue.

2) If you want me to run queries from inside this container, grant permission to install software. If you allow installation, I will run these commands to add a client (and server if desired):
- apt-get update
- apt-get install -y mariadb-client          (to get a client only)
- apt-get install -y mariadb-server mariadb-client   (to get server+client)

After installation I will start the server (if installed) and create/connect to databases and then proceed to run SQL as you request. I will show each SQL statement in the exact one-line markdown block when ready to operate.

Tell me which option you choose (provide the question and/or credentials, or permit installation).",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}

New Terminal Output:

root@2178bed1d79c:/app#

{
  "analysis": "No new terminal activity. Previous checks show this container has no MySQL client or server installed, no MySQL processes, no MySQL config or data directories, and /app is empty. Therefore I cannot run or test any SQL here until I either (A) receive a database question plus connection details so I can produce SQL for you to run remotely, or (B) am authorized to install a MySQL/MariaDB client (and optionally server) into this container so I can run queries locally.",
  "plan": "Tell me which of the following you want to do next and I will proceed accordingly:

1) Provide the database question (and optionally host, port, user, password). I will explain the approach and then produce exactly one SQL statement (in the required single-line SQL markdown block) for you to execute against your database. After you run it and paste the raw MySQL output back here, I'll parse it and continue.

2) Permit me to install a client (or server + client) in this container. If you allow installation, I'll run apt-get update and then apt-get install -y mariadb-client (for client only) or apt-get install -y mariadb-server mariadb-client (for local server+client). After installation I will start the server (if installed) and then we can run SQL here. I will not install anything until you explicitly approve.

Please reply with your choice and, if choosing option 1, include the DB question and any connection info (if you want me to craft SQL that uses specific schema/table names).",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}

New Terminal Output:

root@2178bed1d79c:/app#

{
  "analysis": "No changes since my last check. The container has no MySQL client or server installed (mysql command not found), no mysqld process, no MySQL config or data directories, and the /app directory is empty. Because of that I cannot run any SQL here. I also do not have any database question, schema, or connection credentials from you to craft a query for a remote server.",
  "plan": "You have two options; tell me which you choose and I will proceed accordingly:

Option A — You provide the database question (and optionally connection details: host, port, user, password, database). I will explain my reasoning and then produce exactly one SQL statement (in a single-line SQL code block as required) for you to run on your MySQL server. Once you run it and paste the raw MySQL output back here, I will parse it and continue.

Option B — You permit me to install a MySQL/MariaDB client (and optionally a server) inside this container so I can run SQL locally. If you permit installation, I will run these commands (I will not run them until you approve):
1) apt-get update
2a) apt-get install -y mariadb-client     (client only)
OR
2b) apt-get install -y mariadb-server mariadb-client   (server + client)
3) If server installed, start the service (service mysql start or systemctl start mariadb) and secure/setup root password as needed.

If you choose Option A, provide the question and (optionally) credentials. If you choose Option B, confirm which packages to install (client only or server+client) and I will proceed and then run discovery commands and connect to the DB.
",
  "commands": [],
  "task_complete": false
}

I will show each SQL statement in the exact one-line markdown block when ready to operate.

Please reply with which option you choose and, if choosing option 1, provide the DB question and any connection info. If choosing option 2, confirm whether to install client-only or server+client.",

You are an AI assistant tasked with solving command-line tasks in a Linux environment. You will be given a task description and the output from previously executed commands. Your goal is to solve the task by providing batches of shell commands.

Format your response as JSON with the following structure:

{
  "analysis": "Analyze the current state based on the terminal output provided. What do you see? What has been accomplished? What still needs to be done?",
  "plan": "Describe your plan for the next steps. What commands will you run and why? Be specific about what you expect each command to accomplish.",
  "commands": [
    {
      "keystrokes": "ls -la\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    },
    {
      "keystrokes": "cd project\n",
      "duration": 0.1
    }
  ],
  "task_complete": true
}

Required fields:
- "analysis": Your analysis of the current situation
- "plan": Your plan for the next steps
- "commands": Array of command objects to execute

Optional fields:
- "task_complete": Boolean indicating if the task is complete (defaults to false if not present)

Command object structure:
- "keystrokes": String containing the exact keystrokes to send to the terminal (required)
- "duration": Number of seconds to wait for the command to complete before the next command will be executed (defaults to 1.0 if not present)

IMPORTANT: The text inside "keystrokes" will be used completely verbatim as keystrokes. Write commands exactly as you want them sent to the terminal:
- You must end every command with a newline (\n) or it will not execute.
- For special key sequences, use tmux-style escape sequences:
  - C-c for Ctrl+C
  - C-d for Ctrl+D

The "duration" attribute specifies the number of seconds to wait for the command to complete (default: 1.0) before the next command will be executed. On immediate tasks (e.g., cd, ls, echo, cat) set a duration of 0.1 seconds. On commands (e.g., gcc, find, rustc) set a duration of 1.0 seconds. On slow commands (e.g., make, python3 [long running script], wget [file]) set an appropriate duration as you determine necessary.

It is better to set a smaller duration than a longer duration. It is always possible to wait again if the prior output has not finished, by running {"keystrokes": "", "duration": 10.0} on subsequent requests to wait longer. Never wait longer than 60 seconds; prefer to poll to see intermediate result status.

Important notes:
- Each command's keystrokes are sent exactly as written to the terminal
- Do not include extra whitespace before or after the keystrokes unless it's part of the intended command
- Extra text before or after the JSON will generate warnings but be tolerated
- The JSON must be valid - use proper escaping for quotes and special characters within strings
- Commands array can be empty if you want to wait without taking action
